projectPurpose: To provide a command-line utility for Windows that allows users to quickly and easily run commands with elevated (administrator) privileges from a standard, unelevated command prompt or terminal session, replicating the familiar `sudo` experience from Unix-like operating systems.
mainFeatures: Allows running elevated commands (as administrator) from an unelevated command line context.
Provides a familiar command-line experience similar to Unix/Linux sudo.
Integrates with User Account Control (UAC) for elevation prompts.
Supports running applications in a new elevated console window or within the current window.
Available for Windows 11 builds 26045 and later.

alternatives.name: runas
mainFeatures: Run programs as a different user.
Can be used to run programs as Administrator.
Supports specifying arguments to the program.
Can load or bypass the user profile of the secondary user.

alternatives.name: gsudo
mainFeatures: Sudo equivalent for Windows with a similar user experience.
Elevates commands or shells with elevated permissions in the current or a new console window.
Integrates with UAC.
Supports various shells (Cmd, PowerShell, WSL, git-bash, etc.).
Handles exit codes, StdIn/Out/Err redirection.

alternatives.name: Elevate
alternatives.license: Open Source or Freeware (License details vary)
mainFeatures: Executes a command with UAC privilege elevation.
Useful for working inside command prompts or batch files.
Starts a process in an elevated state from a non-elevated shell.
Can keep the current directory.

alternatives.name: PowerShell Start-Process -Verb runAs
mainFeatures: Programmatically start processes with different verbs, including 'runAs' for elevation.
Can be used within scripts to achieve elevation.
Integrates with UAC.
Provides control over process creation.

marketPositioning: Microsoft's "Sudo for Windows" is positioned as an official, modern command-line tool for streamlined privilege elevation on Windows, specifically targeting users familiar with the Unix/Linux `sudo` command. It differentiates itself from the traditional `runas` command by focusing on elevating the current user's process via UAC for single commands, providing a more ergonomic experience for this specific task. Its open-source nature and backing by Microsoft establish it as the official solution in this niche, complementing existing elevation methods rather than replacing them entirely.
